Award.AwardTitle: The UC Davis Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Noyce phase I project is a collaboration between UC Davis, three local school districts and four community colleges to recruit and prepare secondary science and mathematics teachers for California's secondary schools. The project's goals are to 1) recruit and retain students in the (undergraduate) Mathematics and Science Teaching program (MAST), particularly underrepresented minorities; 2) increase the overall number of science and mathematics credential candidates in the UC Davis Teacher Education Program by a minimum of 50%; and 3) retain at least 80% of the Noyce Scholars in their school districts for a minimum of four years. Each year, three one-year and one two-year scholarships are targeted for community college transfer students. Scholarship recipients complete their student teaching in schools serving substantial numbers of students who are economically disadvantaged and/or English learners. The program aims to produce sixty six new science and mathematics teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
UC Davis Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program

 

The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program was established at UC Davis with the goal of increasing the quality and quantity of ethnically and culturally diverse K-12 STEM teachers in California. This goal can be accomplished by granting scholarships to promising UC Davis undergraduate and graduate students in STEM fields, and providing a range of valuable STEM teacher-education experiences to a broad community of undergraduate students associated with the UC Davis CalTeach/MAST (Math and Science Teaching) program. UC Davis Noyce Scholars represent a growing variety of undergraduate majors in physics, chemistry, engineering, and geology, with mathematics and the biological sciences representing the majority.  The scholarships provide incentives to highly qualified math and science students to pursue teacher training – whether at the undergraduate level through the internship-based CalTeach/MAST program, or in the single-subject teacher credentialing program in the School of Education at UC Davis. $10,000 scholarships were offered through competitive application to upper-division students who completed CalTeach/MAST coursework.  $15,000 scholarships were available to students entering the single subject teaching credential program at UC Davis in mathematics or science. Offered for the first time at UC Davis in the 2011-12 school year, this scholarship largely covered tuition and fees for one year at UC Davis.

 

Over the seven years of the grant tenure, 71 scholarships were awarded.  93% of those students have gone into STEM education, with 92% of them teaching in high-needs districts. Of the five who have not yet gone into teaching, three are expected to do so within the next two years.  Sixty-two of the 66 Scholars who went directly into teaching are still teaching, and all but one is teaching in a high-needs district.  UC Davis Noyce Scholars are highly sought after by principals in regional schools, and once hired, are respected and effective leaders in those schools.

 

UC Davis Noyce Scholars enter California classrooms as enthusiastic and well-prepared teachers and role models. They inspire the students they teach, transmitting knowledge and critical thinking skills. In addition, many have already taken leadership roles in their districts and regions, participating in professional growth opportunities, leading workshops, serving on boards, and mentoring undergraduates at both the community college and university level. Through the Robert Noyce Scholarship Program, UC Davis has been able to strengthen the educational pipeline, increasing the quality, quantity, and diversity of STEM educators teaching in California K-12 schools.
